theoryTitle: Bartolomeo's Barrier Can't Be Broken by Haki
theoryText: After Bartolomeo's barrier ability was revealed in Episode 637, fans theorized that his barrier is absolutely indestructible, even against Haki-infused attacks. Evidence includes Maynard's failed attempt to break the barrier with a Haki-imbued axe, suggesting that the Bari Bari no Mi creates a defense that transcends normal Devil Fruit weaknesses. Some fans speculate this makes Bartolomeo nearly invincible defensively, potentially able to withstand attacks from even the strongest characters like admirals or emperors.
author: Various One Piece community members
platform: Quora, Worstgen Forums, One Piece Wiki Forums

spoilerStatus.spoilerDescription: Discusses Bartolomeo's barrier capabilities throughout Block B

resolution: The barrier has been shown to withstand extremely powerful attacks, including Admiral attacks, but its absolute limits remain untested. The theory is partially confirmed as the barrier appears nearly indestructible in practice.

theoryTitle: Barrier Awakening Could Create Multiple Barriers or Barrier Weapons
theoryText: Following the revelation of Bartolomeo's barrier powers in Episode 637, fans theorized about what his Devil Fruit awakening might entail. Popular theories include: (1) The ability to create multiple barriers simultaneously instead of just one, (2) The ability to project barriers at a distance or turn others into barrier users, (3) The creation of offensive barrier weapons like barrier spears or swords, (4) Making entire areas or structures into barriers. This theory highlights how defensive Devil Fruits might gain offensive capabilities through awakening.
author: Various One Piece community members

spoilerStatus.spoilerDescription: Speculative theory about future developments, no concrete spoilers

resolution: As of the current story, Bartolomeo's awakening has not been revealed, so this theory remains speculative.

theoryText: When Chinjao's grudge against Garp was revealed in Episode 637, some fans theorized that the 'precious treasure' Garp took from Chinjao wasn't just his drill-shaped head, but actually Chinjao's younger sister's heart. The theory proposed that Garp and Chinjao were once friends, but Garp fell in love with and 'stole' Chinjao's sister, who became Luffy's grandmother (Dragon's mother). This would make Chinjao Luffy's great-uncle and explain the deep personal nature of his grudge beyond just the physical defeat. The theory suggested this was why Chinjao wanted to kill Luffy specifically - to hurt Garp's family bloodline.
author: One Piece community theorists

spoilerStatus.spoilerDescription: Contains speculation about Luffy's family tree and Chinjao's backstory

resolution: This theory was debunked in Chapter 719/Episode 649 when it was revealed that Chinjao's 'precious treasure' was literally his fortune hidden in an ice continent, accessible only with his drill-shaped head. The treasure was not a person or family member, but actual gold and valuables.

theoryText: After seeing Bellamy's brutal fighting style in Episode 637, fans theorized that his increased ruthlessness and determination to prove himself in the tournament was the beginning of a redemption arc. The theory suggested that Bellamy was trying to earn Doflamingo's respect and prove he wasn't weak anymore after his humiliating defeat by Luffy in Jaya. Some fans predicted Bellamy would eventually turn against Doflamingo and ally with Luffy, showing character growth from his earlier villain role. His phrase 'This is the New World! There's no room for mercy!' was interpreted as him trying to convince himself he needed to be cruel to survive.
author: One Piece anime community

spoilerStatus.spoilerDescription: Discusses Bellamy's character development throughout Dressrosa arc

resolution: This theory was essentially confirmed as Bellamy's story in Dressrosa showed his internal conflict, his eventual realization about Doflamingo's manipulation, and his final confrontation with Luffy where mutual respect was established. While not a traditional 'ally,' Bellamy did show significant character growth and redemption.

theoryTitle: Luffy's Disguise Will Lead to Multiple Block Battles
theoryText: After Luffy's identity was exposed by Chinjao in Episode 637, fans theorized that Luffy would have to fight his way through multiple blocks instead of just Block C. With both Chinjao and Cavendish targeting him, fans predicted chaotic scenarios where Luffy would be forced to defend himself against competitors from other blocks while trying to maintain his Lucy disguise. Some theorized he might even be banned from the tournament entirely, forcing him to steal the Mera Mera no Mi through alternative means.
author: One Piece community

spoilerStatus.spoilerDescription: Discusses tournament progression and Luffy's participation

resolution: Luffy did face complications due to his exposed identity, leading to confrontations with Chinjao in Block C. However, he didn't fight through multiple blocks as predicted. The situation evolved differently than theorized, though the core idea of his identity causing problems was accurate.
